quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: The moment you stop making progress in your career is the moment you start looking for another job.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: A simple diagnostic for retention and career satisfaction: stalled progress triggers job-search behavior.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: I've coached almost a thousand people because I think there's a billion people a year who switched jobs and ultimately most of them end up with a job that's worse than the one they were at, but they don't know how to find it. They don't know themselves well enough.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: A striking scale/data point paired with a root-cause claim: job switching often fails due to poor self-understanding.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: I call it a jobcation, which is a job I can go do with one hand tie by hide my back so I can rest and recover to go do something else.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: A tactical concept for career transitions: take a deliberately low-demand role to recover and reset before the next move.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: The moment you are comfortable doing nothing, you know who you are again, and you can actually figure this out.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: Counterintuitive guidance that reframes “doing nothing” as a prerequisite for clarity and better career decisions.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: There's difference between product features and product experiences, and what you start to realize is it's the experiences that keep you at your job.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: A transferable mental model from product to careers: retention is driven more by lived experience than surface attributes.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Experimentation is increasingly essential for driving growth and for understanding the performance of new features.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A clear practitioner takeaway on why teams should invest in experimentation as a core growth and product-learning capability.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Eppo does all that and more with advanced statistical methods that can help you shave weeks off experiment time and accessible UI for diving deeper into performance and out-of-the-box reporting that helps you avoid annoying prolonged analytic cycles.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Highlights concrete levers (stats methods, UI, reporting) that reduce cycle time and improve decision-making rigor in experimentation.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Today we currently help over 9,000 companies including some start-up household names like Atlassian, Ramp, and LangChain start and scale their security programs and ultimately build trust by automating compliance, centralizing GRC, and accelerating security reviews.
quotes.speaker: Christina Cacioppo
quotes.context: Provides a specific adoption data point and a concise methodology (automate compliance, centralize GRC, accelerate reviews) for building trust via security programs.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: And our joke, we started this compliance company, so you don't have to.
quotes.speaker: Christina Cacioppo
quotes.context: A memorable, quotable framing that captures the value proposition of outsourcing compliance overhead through automation/software.

quotes.topic_title: Why Job Moves: solving the talent problem
quotes.text: I've been asking founders for 15 years, what are the top three things that you really... If you could wave a magic wand and solve, what would it be? And talent was always on that list.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: Highlights a repeatable diagnostic question founders can use—and underscores that talent is a persistent, top-tier problem.

quotes.topic_title: Why Job Moves: solving the talent problem
quotes.text: over the last 15 years we've interviewed over a thousand people. I've coached almost a thousand people.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: Establishes the scale of evidence behind the book’s guidance and methodology.

quotes.topic_title: Why Job Moves: solving the talent problem
quotes.text: there's a billion people a year who switch jobs and ultimately most of them end up with a job that's worse than the one they were at, but they don't know how to find it and part of it is they don't know themselves well enough.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: A counterintuitive claim about job switching that reframes the problem as self-understanding, not just market conditions or resume tactics.

quotes.topic_title: Why Job Moves: solving the talent problem
quotes.text: Jobs-to-be-Done is a very powerful concept, but the reality is I think it's actually more beneficial when you apply it to things.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: A practical mental model: treat JTBD as an applied tool you can port into domains like careers, sales, and education.

quotes.topic_title: Big idea: employees hire companies
quotes.text: And ultimately luck is when opportunity meets preparedness.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: A memorable mental model that reframes “getting lucky” as something you can actively increase by preparing for opportunities.

quotes.topic_title: Big idea: employees hire companies
quotes.text: And so you started to realize this is a much bigger thing around that employees hire companies more than companies hire employees.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: A contrarian thesis that flips the usual power dynamic and changes how people should approach career decisions.

quotes.topic_title: Big idea: employees hire companies
quotes.text: And if that's the case, how do I prepare you as an employee to know how to hire your job every single day, wherever you're at, how do you make sure you're doing the things you want to do and you're making progress in your life?
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: Actionable guidance to treat your current role as something you continually “choose,” focusing on daily progress rather than waiting for a job change.

quotes.topic_title: Big idea: employees hire companies
quotes.text: Because the moment you stop making progress in your career is the moment you start looking for another job.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: A practical diagnostic for retention and career satisfaction: stagnation triggers job-search behavior.

quotes.topic_title: Job features vs job experiences
quotes.text: There's difference between product features and product experiences.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: A simple mental model to reframe job decisions the same way we evaluate products: outcomes come from experiences, not feature checklists.

quotes.topic_title: Job features vs job experiences
quotes.text: the experiences that keep you at your job and the good experiences and bad experiences are the things that actually pull it together, which is how attributes work through time and space.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: Highlights retention as an accumulation of lived moments over time, not isolated attributes like title or comp.

quotes.topic_title: Job features vs job experiences
quotes.text: Money is a surrogate for respect or I've got bills to pay or I'm falling behind, or the fact is I deserve more.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: Actionable prompt for interviews and career coaching: unpack “money” into the underlying job-to-be-done drivers.

quotes.topic_title: Job features vs job experiences
quotes.text: everybody wants more money, but the question is why do you want more money?
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: A practical diagnostic question to get from surface-level feature demands to the real needs behind them.

quotes.topic_title: Job features vs job experiences
quotes.text: So think of moments where you actually go into a situation and you get energy from it. Well, that's an experience that's not an attribute. At the same time, the fact this is those moments where you go in and you get the life sucked out of you, that's an experience.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: Introduces an “energy drivers vs energy drains” method for identifying the experiences that predict fit and satisfaction.

quotes.topic_title: The four quests behind leaving a job
quotes.text: What we do is we do these interviews and we basically think of it as the ultimate of exit interviews. Why did you really leave this job? And so most of the time people won't tell their companies the truth. And so these are unfiltered interviews around like tell me what was really going on and out of it, we end up getting what we call pushes and pulls and these pushes and pulls is we end up with 13 different pushes.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: Introduces the methodology (unfiltered “ultimate exit interviews”) and the pushes/pulls model as a practical way to diagnose why people actually leave.

quotes.topic_title: The four quests behind leaving a job
quotes.text: But what happened is that when you start to look at all thousand interviews, they fall into one of four buckets.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: A data-backed claim that many messy job-leaving stories reliably cluster into four repeatable “quests.”

quotes.topic_title: The four quests behind leaving a job
quotes.text: One is this bucket of get out. It is sucking my energy. I don't really know what to do, I can't think about what to do next. Help me get out of here so I can actually start to breathe and think. Right?
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: Defines the “Get Out” quest in a memorable way that helps practitioners recognize when the right move is relief first, clarity second.

quotes.topic_title: The four quests behind leaving a job
quotes.text: This is where you like what you're doing, but the fact is that at some point there's just too much of it and you're not doing it in a way that basically you don't like the way you're doing it. And so part of it is pulling you back to basically where you actually have control over the work and control over yourself and control to basically manage your time yourself because at some point we get sucked in and it happens a lot in startups.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: Captures the “Regain Control” quest—useful for diagnosing burnout that isn’t about disliking the work, but losing autonomy and time control.

quotes.topic_title: The four quests behind leaving a job
quotes.text: I found everybody else jobs and then ultimately helped me basically get back to being able to do the work because that's the stuff I love to do.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: A concrete example of “Realign” in action—reshaping scope and structure to return to strengths rather than defaulting to quitting or grinding through.

quotes.topic_title: Why diagnosing pushes and pulls matters
quotes.text: nobody randomly changes jobs, it's just not possible.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: A contrarian JTBD lens: job changes are causal, driven by context and forces rather than randomness.

quotes.topic_title: Why diagnosing pushes and pulls matters
quotes.text: if I don't have enough context, I don't have enough pushes, I can complain about my job, but I'll never make the switch.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: Actionable diagnostic: complaints don’t translate into change until enough “pushes” accumulate in context.

quotes.topic_title: Why diagnosing pushes and pulls matters
quotes.text: if she could name me four of the pushes, I knew she was already looking for another job.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: A practical heuristic for predicting churn: the ability to enumerate multiple pushes signals readiness to leave.

quotes.topic_title: Why diagnosing pushes and pulls matters
quotes.text: it's not anyone push, but it's when the set of pushes come together and really give you enough energy to go like, yeah, I can't see where to go.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: A mental model of “energy” as the sum of pushes—change happens when multiple forces compound.

quotes.topic_title: Why diagnosing pushes and pulls matters
quotes.text: it's not more money. Like 53% of the people who basically said they got more money, did not get more money.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: A data-backed challenge to conventional wisdom: compensation is often a post-hoc justification, not the true pull.

quotes.topic_title: Energy drivers and drains: finding your requirements
quotes.text: So it's like I don't want to intimidate people by nine steps, but the reality is this is a really big one, which is to go back through your career and even back to college, I've taken people back to high school and basically talk about those moments where you got energy, you walked into a situation and you literally were like, "Oh my God, I got so excited about this and =why did I get excited?"
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: A practical reflection method: scan your history for specific “energizing moments” and interrogate why they felt energizing.

quotes.topic_title: Energy drivers and drains: finding your requirements
quotes.text: It's one, capturing those moments and then dissecting those moments to say, what was it about that context that gave you energy that made you excited, right?
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: A repeatable process: capture peak-energy moments, then dissect the context to extract your underlying requirements.

quotes.topic_title: Energy drivers and drains: finding your requirements
quotes.text: But the reality is most people spend 95% of their time doing the work that sucks their energy so they get the 5% of the joy of the work they do.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: A counterintuitive diagnosis that explains why many roles feel miserable even when they contain some enjoyable work.

quotes.topic_title: Energy drivers and drains: finding your requirements
quotes.text: And what I realized is that if you can pull that ratio to 40% energy drive or drain or 50 50, you don't even know you're working anymore because you're just used to basically always doing the grind to get where you want to go.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: A concrete target for redesigning work: shift the energy-driver/drain ratio to transform how work feels day-to-day.

quotes.topic_title: Energy drivers and drains: finding your requirements
quotes.text: So what I've learned is that if I let people do it over a two-week period or so, they start to remember things like I say, go for a walk and just think about that job you had back then.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: A simple implementation detail: use a two-week reflection window (including walks) to surface forgotten energy drivers/drains.

quotes.topic_title: Quick exercises and common examples
quotes.text: think about two or three meetings, think about two or three projects, two or three things that you did where literally when you went into it, you actually had an X amount of energy and when you came out of it, you actually had 2X, 3X, four x of energy and say, what was it about that project or that meeting or that team that gave you so much energy and to be able to make it explicit. So actually that becomes a design requirement for your next job.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: A concrete reflection exercise that turns energizing moments into explicit “design requirements” for choosing or shaping your next role.

quotes.topic_title: Quick exercises and common examples
quotes.text: I always talk about strength finders and I tell people to say, I want to know the bottom five.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: A counterintuitive twist on strengths assessments: focus on weaknesses to locate hidden energy drains and risk areas.

quotes.topic_title: Quick exercises and common examples
quotes.text: So ultimately I'm treating you as a product to understand what are your requirements basically to be able to make progress.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for career decisions: apply product thinking to yourself to clarify requirements for progress.

quotes.topic_title: Quick exercises and common examples
quotes.text: So this is where you have to abstract it beyond the beach. Why do you like to go to the beach?
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: A practical prompt for moving from surface-level preferences to underlying causal drivers you can actually design work around.

quotes.topic_title: Quick exercises and common examples
quotes.text: It's about abstracting it down to a level of causation so you understand what causes the beach to be a fun place.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: A crisp methodology statement: dig to causal mechanisms (not labels) to make preferences transferable into job requirements.

quotes.topic_title: Job design, AI help, and team complementarity
quotes.text: But what I've learned is if I wrap a process around something I love to do, I actually ruin it. But if I wrap a process about something I really hate to do and gamify it, I can actually get through it.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: A counterintuitive rule for when to systematize work: process can kill joy, but can make drains tolerable.

quotes.topic_title: Job design, AI help, and team complementarity
quotes.text: Will just help you start to articulate those things because when it comes down to it, here's the craziest part to me of... One of the crazy parts, is the job descriptions are made up.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: Reframes job descriptions as negotiable artifacts rather than fixed truths, opening the door to redesigning roles.

quotes.topic_title: Job design, AI help, and team complementarity
quotes.text: But if you actually reframe this and say, how do I get the job to fit the person? And you start to realize I can change the design of the job and now they love what they do, they're never going to leave.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: A practical mental model for retention and performance: redesign the role around the person instead of forcing fit.

quotes.topic_title: Job design, AI help, and team complementarity
quotes.text: We to map the features to the experiences that actually make it happen because features are actually static, your job title, but if I get the title, I can impress others, I can make people think, that makes me feel like I'm making products to go from a director to a VP.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: A JTBD-style method: translate static “features” (like title) into the underlying experience and progress someone is seeking.

quotes.topic_title: Job design, AI help, and team complementarity
quotes.text: And what happens through time is that title will wear down over time. And so it has a depreciation to it that now I've been a VP, now I got to be a C-level person.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: Highlights why chasing status features can be a treadmill—useful for career decisions and role design.

quotes.topic_title: Prototyping your next job with informational interviews
quotes.text: when you can distill this down to the things that give you energy and what you're good at, the thing that I think has been most powerful is, again, treating you like a product. How do we prototype different job positions for you?
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: A practical mental model for career moves: treat yourself like a product and run discovery via prototyping roles.

quotes.topic_title: Prototyping your next job with informational interviews
quotes.text: it's this notion of prototyping wide because what we realize is most people don't feel like they have agency to go anywhere else.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: A counterintuitive push to explore broadly, grounded in the observation that perceived lack of agency limits career options.

quotes.topic_title: Prototyping your next job with informational interviews
quotes.text: And the reality is if you're really good at the things you're good at, they're used in a lot of other places.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: Reframes skills as portable across industries, encouraging wider search than the typical same-industry move.

quotes.topic_title: Prototyping your next job with informational interviews
quotes.text: And this does two things. It gives you practice talking about yourself and talking to other people, which most people haven't done in a long time. And the other part is it allows you to start to put yourself in that situation and go like, well, this really worked for me or not.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: Explains why informational interviews are a high-leverage prototype: they build narrative skill and test real fit before applying.

quotes.topic_title: Prototyping your next job with informational interviews
quotes.text: job descriptions should really be, here's the context we're in. Here's what this role is about. Here's what progress means in this role and here's how we will actually reward you for actually doing this work. And it's just not that way.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: A clear template for what job descriptions should include, highlighting why candidates must do discovery beyond postings.

quotes.topic_title: Aiming your search: quests plus requirements
quotes.text: They're both. So the thing is there's got to be a push and then at some point if there's just push and there's no pull, the reality is that then you're just going to about your job.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: Highlights the necessity of having both dissatisfaction (push) and an attractive direction (pull) to actually change roles.

quotes.topic_title: Aiming your search: quests plus requirements
quotes.text: So part of it is the push actually gives you the energy to look, but you have to have the pulls on the other side to know which direction to go.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: A practical mental model: push supplies momentum, pull supplies direction for a job search.

quotes.topic_title: Aiming your search: quests plus requirements
quotes.text: Think of it as like a compass. And so these quests help you understand, am I going north, am I going south? Am I going east? Am I going west?
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: Provides a memorable metaphor for using “quests” to orient decisions rather than relying on generic role descriptions.

quotes.topic_title: Aiming your search: quests plus requirements
quotes.text: And ultimately based on that, that's going to shape how we actually then load your strengths, your energy drivers, your energy drains as air, how are we going to aim this thing? So it's about aiming where you go next.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: Actionable guidance to refine targeting by mapping strengths plus energy drivers/drains to the next role.

quotes.topic_title: Aiming your search: quests plus requirements
quotes.text: And then you do this prototyping where you interview people, you make a broad list of potential places and jobs and then interview them about what that life is like to see which checkboxes are checked.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Describes a concrete methodology—prototype your next job via interviews to validate fit against your checklist.

quotes.topic_title: Trade-offs, compensation, and progress over perfection
quotes.text: No job is perfect and ultimately people are looking for the thing that checks all the boxes and you start to realize nothing checks all the boxes. So what are you willing to give up to get?
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: A crisp trade-off framing practitioners can use to evaluate roles by explicitly naming what they’ll sacrifice to get what they value most.

quotes.topic_title: Trade-offs, compensation, and progress over perfection
quotes.text: So you can't go like, "Oh God, I should get more money." It's like, this is how it is and this is a choice you made live with it, but put a timeframe on it.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: Actionable advice for committing to a chosen trade-off without resentment—while timeboxing the decision to preserve optionality.

quotes.topic_title: Trade-offs, compensation, and progress over perfection
quotes.text: I can actually pay people less if I give them better experiences.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: A counterintuitive compensation insight: experience and learning can be a deliberate part of the “total package,” affecting retention and motivation.

quotes.topic_title: Trade-offs, compensation, and progress over perfection
quotes.text: when you overpay people, what happens is that they actually become more and more scared that they will lose it, and then they become more and more conservative because they don't want to rock the boat and they actually don't work. They do what they're told as opposed to do what they should do.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: A provocative observation about incentives: overpay can increase risk-aversion and reduce initiative, hurting innovation and ownership.

quotes.topic_title: Trade-offs, compensation, and progress over perfection
quotes.text: the more I actually get comfortable with making trade-offs, the fact is the more satisfied I become.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for career decisions: satisfaction rises when you accept trade-offs rather than expecting an “all boxes checked” outcome.
